title: General Paper 1 (Psych March 2021)
description: Final Qualifying Examination General Paper One from March 2021 (Psychiatry/General). Contains 49 questions covering General Nursing, Pharmacology, Anatomy, and Professionalism.

questions.question: Gingivitis is a periodontal disease characterized by:

options.text: Reddened gums, loosening of teeth, pockets of pus formation
Tooth decay, loose teeth, bleeding gums
Reddened gums, purulent discharge pockets formation
Bleeding gums, swollen gums, reddened gums

questions.explanation: Gingivitis is inflammation of the gums characterized by redness (erythema), swelling (edema), and bleeding. Loosening of teeth indicates Periodontitis.

questions.question: The type of fracture in which the bone splinters into several fragments is:
questions.explanation: A comminuted fracture involves the bone breaking into three or more pieces (splintering).

questions.question: A well functioning chest tube drainage system should have:

options.text: No fluctuation of water in the water seal chamber
Drainage system maintained above the patient's chest
Fluctuation of water in water seal chamber during inhalation and exhalation

questions.explanation: Fluctuation (tidaling) indicates the system is patent and functioning. Continuous bubbling indicates a leak.

questions.question: Chvostek's sign indicates:
questions.explanation: Chvostek's sign (facial twitching) is a sign of neuromuscular excitability caused by low calcium (Hypocalcemia).

questions.question: The inauguration of the safe motherhood initiative in Kenya was in:
questions.explanation: The Safe Motherhood Initiative was launched globally in Nairobi, Kenya, in 1987.

questions.question: All HIV exposed infants should be tested first at:
questions.explanation: Early Infant Diagnosis (EID) using DNA PCR is recommended at 6 weeks.

questions.question: The ethical principle in nursing that states that the action one takes should promote good is:
questions.explanation: Beneficence is the obligation to do good.

questions.question: The fundamental responsibility of the nurse according to the ICN code is to:
questions.explanation: The four fundamental responsibilities are: promote health, prevent illness, restore health, and alleviate suffering.

questions.question: Bioavailability refers to the amount of drug:

options.text: That must be given to reach therapeutic level
That reaches the general circulation unaltered from the site of administration
Excreted unchanged from the body tissues

questions.explanation: Bioavailability is the fraction of the dose that reaches systemic circulation unchanged.

questions.question: Which antibiotic has a bacteriostatic action?
questions.explanation: Erythromycin (Macrolide) is bacteriostatic (inhibits growth). Penicillins/Cephalosporins are bactericidal.

questions.question: Active transport involves transport of substances:
questions.explanation: Active transport requires energy to move substances against (up) the concentration gradient.

questions.question: Macrophages found in the spaces between liver cells are called:
questions.explanation: Kupffer cells are the resident macrophages of the liver.

questions.question: A typical reflex arc neuropathway is:
questions.explanation: Stimulus -> Receptor -> Sensory Neuron -> CNS -> Motor Neuron -> Effector.

questions.question: Select the TRUE statements regarding infection control:

options.text: The sterilization process ensures that all micro-organisms including bacterial spores are destroyed
Glutaraldehyde (Cidex) is a high level disinfectant
Sterilization only kills bacteria, not spores

questions.explanation: Sterilization destroys all forms of life including spores. Glutaraldehyde is a high-level disinfectant.

questions.question: When examining a patient with abdominal pain the nurse should assess:

options.text: The symptomatic quadrant first and then last

questions.explanation: Palpating the painful area last prevents guarding and pain that would interfere with the rest of the exam.

questions.question: A female patient with a terminal illness is in denial if which of the following is present?
questions.explanation: Denial (the first stage of grief) often manifests as shock, disbelief, and dismay.

questions.question: Passive immunization (antitoxin) is commonly used for treatment of:
questions.explanation: Diphtheria is treated with Diphtheria Antitoxin (passive immunity). TB, Cholera, etc., use vaccines (active).

questions.question: The toxins produced by bacteria:

options.text: Interfere with physiological process in the body

questions.explanation: Bacterial toxins damage host tissues and disrupt physiological functions.

questions.question: Which of the following is a measurable outcome statement?

options.text: Patient will report pain acuity less that 4 on a scale of 0-10
Patient will take pain medication every 4 hours

questions.explanation: Outcome A is specific and measurable (scale of 0-10, threshold <4). Option D is an intervention.

questions.question: The drugs classified as narcotic analgesics include:
questions.explanation: Morphine and Codeine are classic opioid (narcotic) analgesics.

questions.question: The management of a patient with congestive cardiac failure includes:

options.text: Monitoring vital signs four hourly, give diet low in sodium
Weigh patient daily, give diet rich in sodium
Administer broad spectrum antibiotics, weigh the patient monthly
Monitor vital signs 12 hourly, give diet rich in sodium

questions.explanation: CCF management requires sodium restriction and frequent monitoring. High sodium worsens fluid retention.

questions.question: A risk factor of arteriosclerosis and atherosclerosis that can be modified is:
questions.explanation: Obesity and smoking are modifiable lifestyle factors. Age, race, and gender are non-modifiable.

questions.question: Match the cardiac terminology with its description:

pairs.right: Contraction of the heart muscle in a disordered sequence

questions.explanation: Fibrillation is characterized by chaotic, disordered electrical activity and muscle contraction.

questions.question: The priority nursing diagnosis for a patient presenting with an asthmatic attack is:

options.text: Ineffective breathing related to bronchospasms as evidenced by dyspnea
Anxiety related to difficulty in breathing

questions.explanation: Ineffective breathing/Gas exchange is the priority life-threat due to bronchospasm.

questions.question: The extent to which a drug is absorbed and transported to the target site is known as:
questions.explanation: Bioavailability defines the rate/extent of absorption into systemic circulation.

questions.question: The action of hypnotics is to induce:
questions.explanation: Hypnotics induce sleep. Sedatives induce calmness.

questions.question: Addison's disease is caused by:
questions.explanation: Addison's disease is primary adrenal insufficiency (low cortisol/aldosterone).

questions.question: The following hormone is associated with diabetes insipidus:
questions.explanation: DI is caused by a lack of or resistance to ADH.

questions.question: One of characteristics of hyperthyroidism is:
questions.explanation: Hyperthyroidism increases metabolism, causing heat intolerance and elevated temperature.

questions.question: After insertion of contraceptive implants, the client should be instructed to:

options.text: Keep insertion area dry for four to five days
Take a regular dose of paracetamol if soreness persists for more than a week
Clean insertion site daily with warm normal saline

questions.explanation: Keeping the area dry prevents infection of the insertion site wound.

questions.question: Reduction in bone density is a particular concern with the long-term use of:
questions.explanation: Depo Provera is associated with reversible bone mineral density loss.

questions.question: Symptoms of peritonitis include:
questions.explanation: Peritonitis causes a rigid, distended abdomen and absent bowel sounds (ileus).

questions.question: Peptic ulcers characterized by haematemesis and pain that worsens with ingestion of food are:
questions.explanation: Gastric ulcer pain is aggravated by food. Duodenal ulcer pain is relieved by food.

questions.question: Orthostatic hypotension is defined as:

options.text: Slight drop in blood pressure from supine to standing
Significant drop in blood pressure from supine position to standing position
Significant drop in blood pressure from standing to supine
Slight drop in blood pressure from standing to supine

questions.explanation: Orthostatic hypotension is a significant drop (>20mmHg systolic) upon standing.

questions.question: Clinical progression of acute renal failure (AKI) includes which phases in correct order?
questions.explanation: Standard phases: Initiation -> Oliguric -> Diuretic -> Recovery.

questions.question: Hypoalbuminemia in nephrotic syndrome causes:
questions.explanation: Low albumin reduces oncotic pressure, causing fluid to leak into tissues (Generalized edema/Anasarca).

questions.question: An example of electrolyte change that occurs in patients with acute renal failure is:
questions.explanation: Failed kidneys cannot excrete potassium, leading to dangerous Hyperkalemia.

questions.question: Reverse barrier nursing aims at:

options.text: Protecting a susceptible patient from acquiring nosocomial infection
Protecting infected patients from acquiring any other infection
Protecting uninfected patient from acquiring nosocomial infection
Protecting both the susceptible and uninfected patient

questions.explanation: Reverse isolation protects the immunocompromised patient from the environment.

questions.question: The most common micro-organism that causes urinary tract infection (UTI) in females is:
questions.explanation: E. Coli causes the majority of UTIs.

questions.question: The immune system that recognizes antigens or pathogens circulating in blood or lymph is:
questions.explanation: Humoral immunity (B-cells/Antibodies) targets extracellular pathogens in body fluids (humors).

questions.question: State FIVE diagnostic tests carried out on a patient with a gastro-intestinal disorder.
Outline FIVE principles of counseling in family planning.
State FIVE complications of diabetes mellitus.
Outline SIX rights of drug administration.
Order the FIVE stages of grief as described by Elizabeth Kubler Ross:
Explain THREE characteristics of Clostridium tetani.
Outline FOUR clinical features of sickle-cell anaemia.
State FOUR functions of the kidney.
Nursing Professionalism: Select correct Codes, Characteristics, Principles, and Patient Rights.
